conclusion: To determine if the two objects have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), analyze the slopes of the velocity-time graphs for both objects.
The slope of the velocity-time graph represents the acceleration of the object.
Object A is represented by the straight line. Object B is represented by the curved line.
The graph for Object A is a straight line, which means its velocity changes at a constant rate.
The slope of a straight line is constant throughout the entire time interval.
At \( t_1 \), the slope of the line for Object A can be calculated as \(\frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\).
The graph for Object B is a curve, which means its velocity changes at a non-constant rate.
To find the slope at a specific point on a curve, draw a tangent to the curve at that point.
At \( t_1 \), draw a tangent to the curve for Object B. The slope of this tangent line represents the instantaneous acceleration of Object B at \( t_1 \).
Compare the slope of the straight line for Object A at \( t_1 \) with the slope of the tangent line for Object B at \( t_1 \).
If the slopes are equal, then the accelerations are the same. If they are not equal, then the accelerations are different.

The slope of the straight line for Object A at \( t_1 \) is different from the slope of the tangent line to the curve for Object B at \( t_1 \). Therefore, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
